question: Which diagram types should the system support?
context: From spec FR-003: "System MUST support multiple diagram types"
answer_options:
| Option | Answer | Implications |
|--------|--------|--------------|
| A | Core types only: Flowchart, Sequence, and Class diagrams | Smaller initial scope, faster time to market. Covers most common use cases (process flows, interactions, and object models). Can expand later. |
| B | Extended set: Flowchart, Sequence, Class, ER, State, and Component diagrams | Broader initial capability covering both software and data modeling needs. More complex but serves enterprise users better. |
| C | Full suite: All diagram types (Flowchart, Sequence, Class, ER, State, Component, Deployment, Network, etc.) | Maximum flexibility but significantly larger scope and development effort. Risk of delays and quality issues from feature creep. |
| Custom | Specify your own list of diagram types | Define exactly which diagram types matter most for your use case. |

question: What authentication mechanism should the API support?
context: From spec FR-015: "API MUST authenticate and authorize requests"
answer_options:
| Option | Answer | Implications |
|--------|--------|--------------|
| A | API Keys only | Simplest to implement and use. Best for server-to-server integrations. Users generate and manage keys via portal. Requires secure key storage by clients. |
| B | OAuth 2.0 tokens only | Industry-standard for user-facing applications. Supports delegated access and token expiration. More complex setup but better security model for multi-tenant scenarios. |
| C | Both API Keys and OAuth 2.0 | Maximum flexibility - API keys for simple integrations, OAuth for applications. More implementation complexity and maintenance burden. |
| Custom | Different authentication approach | Specify your preferred method (JWT, mTLS, etc.) and rationale. |
